description: Borrowed into Middle English from Old French trepan, from Latin trepanum, from Ancient Greek τρύπανον (trúpanon, “auger, borer”). Doublet of trephine.

entries.meaning: A tool used to bore through rock when sinking shafts.
(medicine) A surgical instrument used to remove a circular section of bone from the skull; a trephine.

verbs.description: trepan (third-person singular simple present trepans, present participle trepanning or trepaning, simple past and past participle trepanned or trepaned)

entries.meaning: (transitive, manufacturing, mining) To create a large hole by making a narrow groove outlining the shape of the hole and then removing the plug of material remaining by less expensive means.
(medicine) To use a trepan; to trephine.

description: Possibly from Old English treppan (“to trap”).

verbs.description: trepan (third-person singular simple present trepans, present participle trepanning, simple past and past participle trepanned)

entries.meaning: (archaic) To ensnare; to seduce, to trick.
examples: O Fie—Sir Peter—would you have ME join in so mean a Trick? to trepan my Brother too?
